instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.U4900: What is U4900? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in older(pre-2013) macbooks.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> only turning on when <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> probe point is touched
threads.message:
I have this board that doesn't show any signs of liquid damage. It shows a green light on the charger when plugged in but nothing else. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.59v and there was no voltage on any of the S5 or S3 rails.
I traced the issue to <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> where there was 0v on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>. I went to the probe point(1227) that is next to the SMC(<CHIP>U4900</CHIP>) to measure <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> and all of a sudden the fans spun and the CPU got warm.
I turned unplugged the charger and plugged it back in but again no fan spin. When I touched the probe point with any metal the fan starts spinning again. There is continuity from that probe point to <RESISTOR>R7940</RESISTOR>. 

I haven't seen something like this before and don't know what I could do to fix this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> only turning on when <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> probe point is touched
threads.message: Remove <RESISTOR>R7940</RESISTOR> and then diode mode on both pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> only turning on when <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> probe point is touched
threads.message:
Before removing <RESISTOR>R7940</RESISTOR> it shows 0.545v on both sides in diode mode.

With <RESISTOR>R7940</RESISTOR> Pin 1 is showing 0.58v in diode mode and Pin shows 0.585v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> only turning on when <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> probe point is touched
threads.message: Hmm, that seems fine. I have had this issue once too and it was a ripped up pad under the SMC, but I confirmed that with diode mode. SMC is suspect now.
